data.name: House Rules
entries: How to thoughtfully and effectively add elements of the bizarre to your game to reignite a sense of awe.

entries.name: Bringing the Bizarre
entries: Crystal Frasier

For all the dragons and spells, the worlds of roleplaying games are strikingly familiar. Gravity pulls things down. Adults grow from children. Fire is hot. These rules mean we can make sense of the fantastic worlds by looking at what's different: mischievous fairies, magic swords, vast underground megastructures. But even these fantastic traits carry a sort of mechanical logic and familiarity. A {@spell fireball} spell may never exist in the real world, but your wizard always knows when they expend that 3rd-level spell slot, they get a 20-foot radius cyclone of fiery death. But those fantastic elements—the altered laws of physics, the in-world legends, the bizarre—are what catch our attention and draw us in.

The bizarre is unexpected, strange, or even a funny way the game world differs from what we expect. Small bits of the bizarre—magic, monsters, or spaceships—all help a setting stand out from our everyday world. But they are almost mundane to anyone who has spent a lifetime watching TV, reading books, and listening to fiction podcasts. Bizarre is where your world breaks its own rules for what is and isn't normal, and when used thoughtfully, it can reignite a sense of wonder.

Adding elements of the bizarre to your game can be a fun way to flesh out the world, build myths or urban legends, or take a momentary break from the normal tone of your campaign. Because the bizarre is often a matter of description rather than major rules changes, it's rarely even that hard once you learn a few key lessons. Many players love a game where the bizarre takes center stage for an adventure, or for the whole campaign, but knowing how to write it means understanding what makes something bizarre and when to use it.

entries.name: Weird Not Wacky
entries: Bizarre doesn't mean chaos and randomness. Change for the sake of change is wackiness, and it can be fun—especially if you plan an adventure in a plane of chaos—but humans are pattern-seeking creatures and like to know some reason lurks behind the unreasonable. Writing the bizarre means change, but with rules. Those rules can be obscure or counterintuitive, but you need at least some cursory guidelines. There needs to be some order, or reason, or internal logic, if only so the players know things are going badly when you break the rules later.

One of the best ways for showcasing the bizarre elements of your world is through contrast. One dot of color stands out brilliantly against a muted background, and likewise a lone strange element in an otherwise familiar situation—especially if no one else seems to notice it—seems far more unsettling and important than a firehose of random changes and oblique references. Likewise, adding some element of the mundane to a magical or supernatural element draws more attention to the rest of the strangeness. Maybe goblins in one adventure—a very familiar monster—have enormous secondary mouths in their stomachs, which speak an alien language and seem far smarter than the goblins themselves. Why? That's for you to figure out, but even if you never explain it, it adds an unsettling twist to something familiar to your players. In the other direction, taking your players to a psychedelic dimension of dreams might be fun, but adding an NPC who dresses and acts like a bored retail worker grounds the experience in something familiar, and makes both the dream world and the NPC seem weirder by the contrast. Consider what the rules are in your setting, follow them to their extremes, and then figure out a way to make your players interact with these unusual edge cases. Consider the {@spell fireball} spell: hold out a pinch of bat guano to create a ball of intense heat. Where does that heat come from? Does the spell open a momentary portal to an elemental plane? Could strange things try to slip out every time a {@spell fireball} spell is cast? What if there's a powerful, ancient fire elemental or genie that created the {@spell fireball} spell and gave it to humans as a means of escaping one tiny piece at a time? Or consider the bat guano—where does it go? And why guano? Is there a demiplane somewhere that collects the material components from spells as a sort of cosmic tax on magic? And if so, does that mean there are demiplanes filled with more valuable components, like the onyx from {@spell create undead} spells?

Consider whatever strange element you want to bring into your game and what rules apply to it. How do the PCs interact with it? What happens when they question it or try to learn more? What happens when they start rolling dice? Don't keep the bizarre completely out of their hands—if you do, your game becomes a lecture—but make sure they know that mastering this bizarre element isn't as easy or straightforward as they may think.

entries.name: Suspention of Disbelief
entries: Suspension of disbelief is the willingness for your players to accept things they know are impossible. If a cartoon rabbit falls off a cliff and then gets up and walks away, we accept that because those are the rules for cartoons. If a gritty detective in a serious movie does the same, we don't accept it, because gritty detectives don't use the same rules as cartoon rabbits. But then you have Who Framed Roger Rabbit, a gritty detective movie that also applies cartoon logic, showing us that there are fuzzy edges to any audience's suspension of disbelief, and those fuzzy edges are where you can play.

Think about what strange elements your players already accept in the game: magical creatures, spells that create ice, spirits of the dead lingering to haunt the living, other dimensions. These are the parts of your story where your players already suspend their disbelief and are more willing to accept the bizarre. If you want an NPC who only speaks in rhyme, then use a creature they have already accepted as magical. If you want a palace of ice in the middle of the desert, connect it to spells they already accept. If you want an adventure that defies all the normal rules, put it in another dimension where they already expect the rules to change.

If you don't want to introduce your bizarre elements in connection to those areas where the PCs have already suspended their disbelief, you can mimic the process many science fiction or supernatural television shows use to introduce their fantastic element. The introduce the element slowly over many episodes, letting audiences adjust their suspension of disbelief a little at a time. Lead your own players away from normal one step at a time. Start with a simple change from the status quo, such as rumors of a new monster, fantastic locations, or a minor magic effect they can't identify or reproduce. You can end up in strange new places like cities of living memories built sideways through time!

entries.name: Reading Your Audience
entries: Every group will accept different levels of the bizarre, so it's important to pay attention to your players and see what strange elements catch their attention or get them excited. It's even more important to notice what elements make them check out or start cracking jokes. Like many story elements, bizarre elements feel more welcome and believable if you drop hints to your group early on. Use NPCs and world lore to spell out not only the rules of your world, but also to foreshadow the creepy times when those rules are broken. If you want an adventure in an Escher-esque world, start a few sessions earlier with a bard spinning campfire tale of a cursed artist who sought literal immortality through their works. If your players find the story interesting, you can feed them a bit more; perhaps the mayor's ancestors vanished mysteriously when they crossed a traveling artist. These small tastes prime the pump for your players' expectations and let you gauge how interested they seem to be.
Adding elements of the bizarre to your game can be a fun way to flesh out the world, build myths or urban legends, or take a momentary break from the normal tone of your campaign.

entries.name: Adding "Bizarre" to Your Own Adventures
entries: Here are a few ideas for you to try.

entries.name: You Bet Your Life
entries: Popular imagery is full of ideas of what the afterlife is, amounting to a grand courtroom where the dead defend their lives. There's also the idea of gambling with death to return to life. If we combine these two ideas, we could see death as a casino, where every major deed in life translates to a chip that can be used in different games depending on the nature of the deed. The dead must win at least one game to move on, or slowly decay into dust, but if they can double their stake they can return to the living. In this scenario, a {@spell resurrection} spell wouldn't bring a dead adventurer back, but instead let the living join them in the casino and play on their behalf—the diamond spell component serving as their ante. This changes resurrecting a fallen friend into its own adventure, and depending on your players, that might be a high-stakes gambling story or a heist.

entries.name: The Goblin Market
entries: In fairy tales, fey, goblins, and witches sometimes trade favors for a person's dearest memories. But what do they do with those memories, and what happens if adventurers need one of those memories to solve a mystery? What if fey and devils have their own otherworldly commodities market where they buy and sell memories like a modern-day stock market, with backroom deals, supply-and-demand, and speculation of which memories will be readily available in the future versus which are rare? Adventurers seeking one memory from the thousands traded every day may drive the price up, requiring them to run a con game to make the memory they need seem worthless. Or they'll have to strike a bizarre deal that requires them to forge very specific memories they agree to trade to a broker—if they can find one they trust.

entries.name: The Mind Maze
entries: A spell that removes a character from the game after one bad roll frustrates even veteran players, as your night of fun with friends has turned into a night of watching your friends have fun. You may want to turn failed saving throws for these "save or die" effects into their own small encounters. The {@spell maze} spell tosses its target into an extradimensional maze for up to 10 minutes and requires an Intelligence test to escape—easy enough for a studied wizard, but frustrating for an action-hero fighter. If the maze is instead inside the spellcaster's mind, then the trapped fighter might run into different, hostile aspects of the wizard's psyche, either battling or roleplaying with them to distract the spellcaster or impose penalties back in the real world. In this scenario, the trapped player still contributes to the adventure, even if they can't win the day single-handedly, and the spell's challenge doesn't feel so hopeless! You can apply this idea to other effects where a failed save leaves a PC incapacitated for minutes or hours. Perhaps a medusa's petrifying gaze launches a character's soul into the Elemental Plane of Earth where they can try to beat elementals at riddle games. Or a sea hag's death glare traps a target's soul inside the raging storm of her own soul alongside however many souls she's claimed before.

data.name: Memorable Monsters
entries: Try these tweaks on the versatile and classic winter wolf to surprise your players.

entries.name: Winter Wolf
entries: E.L. Thomas

entries.name: Take an old-school monster, tweak it, and surprise your players! Whether they are rules lawyers, long-time dungeon crawlers, fellow game masters, or those oh-so-annoying monster-memorizing spoilsports, try our twists on this classic monster.
entries: Since 1977, many a player has faced the icy breath and gnashing jaws of the {@creature winter wolf}. This white, adventurer-eating critter has made (as far as I know) an appearance in every edition of the world's most popular RPG since its creation. In its current incarnation for 5th edition, this large-sized monstrosity comes in at a respectable Challenge 3 (700 XP). I mean, that's pretty realistic for 8 feet long, 4 feet at the shoulder, with an average of 75 hit points and the ability to breathe a 1 5-foot cone of 4d8 cold damage. Add in that it understands both Common and Giant, has Pack Tactics, and is kind of sneaky (Stealth +3, with advantage in snowy terrain), and your PCs have a rough foe to deal with. Think if it is not one, but a pack of 6-10 of these nasty critters coming at your favorite second tier (levels 5-10) party of adventurers—now that's a challenge.

Winter wolves are a super versatile monster that work great for first tier (levels 1-4) and even third tier (levels I I-1 6) play, as well. At low levels, a lone winter wolf can make for a nasty mini-boss fight or an even worse random encounter. At higher levels, the winter wolf becomes the servant, fodder, or ally monster for more powerful foes. Winter wolves serve the role of hunting hounds and guard dogs for frost giants. They make powerful minions for an evil wizard or sorceress. They also make great side quest encounters for single PCs of third tier levels.

If you need inspiration, look no further than the movie The Grey, starring Liam Neeson. Switch out the wolves for winter wolves and switch out the oil pipeline for a trade route and send the PCs hunting. You pretty much can mirror most of the scenes in the movie and have a nasty adventure (just change the plane crash to a wagon crash). So, watch the movie and consider it enjoyable GM homework for using wolves, worgs, and winter wolves on their own as foes for your PCs.

Let us get to tweaking for winter wolves. As I stated earlier, the 5e, Challenge 3 version is pretty good to go as is. But we can do some simple things to surprise your well-read or experienced players. The simplest is to add an Alpha wolf (or two, if you are feeling really nasty), if you are using a pack of winter wolves.

An Alpha is just a cut above the average winter wolf. To make something an Alpha on the fly, just give it max hit points instead of average, and give it +2 AC and +2 bonus on all d20 rolls. If you have time to throw a new stat block together, you just need a few stat bumps. First off, a bump up in natural armor (l mean, being the pack alpha is a tough job). Next, give your Alpha a Hit Dice and challenge increase. You can also add in a new ability, plus up the damage and recharge of the Alpha's attacks. If you do all that, you get the stat block below, as an example.
{@creature Alpha Winter Wolf|RolledTold6}

Let's try another tweak. If you are looking to use a lone winter wolf for, say, a random encounter for second tier PCs or as a solo monster for first tier PCs, then you might go with a winter wolf that is the lone survivor or has been shunned or outcast by their pack. Maybe the outcast lost a battle for pack leadership? In nature, when such occurs, most animals either die, join a new pack, or form their own new pack. The rare few that don't and still manage to eke out survival become quite fierce and savage. Such a winter wolf would make a great side quest for a second tier PC or party, or a whole adventure for a first tier party.

Think about this: What seems to be a pack of massive wolves has been slaughtering any travelers who dare to try and traverse the foothills and low trade trails of a mountain range during winter. The wolves only slaughter livestock and draft animals, but never eat them. They also leave no trace of any humanoids. The PCs are brought in to find and slay these menaces. Now the PCs get to try and figure this very un-wolf-like behavior out and track down what happened to the missing humanoids. When they track down the wolf den, they find the place carpeted with humanoid bones. They also discover there is only one very nasty, scarred, and feral winter wolf!

For this tweak we can just take the Alpha and make a few easy changes. Take away anything to do with a pack, give it some solo abilities, and if you are feeling frisky, make it a Legendary Monster with some Legendary and Lair actions. That is the easiest way to make a single foe feel like multiple foes, and most players hate it when a monster does actions on PCs' turns.
{@creature Feral Outcast Winter Wolf}

Now looking at this outcast, it is a very powerful combatant for Challenge 5, but this wolf is alone. This means all the PCs' attacks and abilities will be focused on it. The outcast does not have any great saving throws, and besides the cold breath, it is a melee fighter. Speed 50 ft.

So beating it only takes trapping it or keeping it at range. The Army of One ability makes that tough, but Mental-based spell saves will end the outcast. Also, all damage except Cold Damage works on it. One ranger with a long bow and one of the nastier ranged weapon feats will whittle away at the outcast's Hit Points in only a few rounds. If that ranger has at least three buddies, then the fight will be fun and interesting, but likely not go any way in the outcast's favor.

This is what you want when tweaking a monster. Make it a surprise to your players. Let the tweaks make the combat or encounter interesting. Last, but not least, make the monster beatable. In the end you want the PCs to win. You just want to rough them up and worry them while they do.

item.name: Lightning Bottle
entries: A purple-hued flask that sparks of tiny lightning can be seen dancing within. As an action, you can throw this flask up to 20 feet, shattering it on impact. Make a ranged attack against a creature or object, treating the lightning bottle as an improvised weapon. On a hit, the target takes {@damage 2d6} lightning damage, and if the target takes damage from this attack, it cannot take a reaction until your next turn.

item.name: Potion of Jumping
entries: When you drink this potion, you gain the effects of the {@spell jump} spell. This greenish, somewhat viscous liquid shows a tiny tuft of rabbit fur suspended in it, which disappears when opened and is replaced by a musky, frog-like smell.

item.name: Hot Air Balloon
entries: See {@vehicle Hot Air Balloon|RolledTold1}.

item.name: Fan of Air Portal Opening
entries: This illustrious fan is made of alternating black and white feathers, mounted on a long golden handle that ends in the shape of a key. Once a day it can open an already existing portal between the Plane of Air and the Material Plane. The fan can close the portal as well. If the portal is not closed by the use of the fan, it will automatically close in two hours. This item does not create portals; it simply opens those which already exist. The fan recharges 24 hours after it's used to open or close a portal.

entries: The carafe sloshes when shaken, as if it contains liquid. The carafe weighs 1 pound. You can use an action to open the lid and speak one of the three command words, whereupon an amount of hot chocolate or cold chocolate milk (your choice) pours out of the flask. The chocolate stops pouring out at the start of your next turn. Choose from the following options: Tall (12 oz.), Grande (16 oz.), Venti (20 oz.).

Flawed Seeing Stone
entries: Unlike a typical crystal ball, this rough cut and blemished chunk of amber is about 6 inches in diameter. While touching it, an attuned user can cast a limited version of the {@spell scrying} spell. The user can only use scrying on a location they have visited before, not a creature. Save for that limitation, it functions exactly as a {@item crystal ball}.

item.name: The Mauve Stone
item.reqAttune: by a sorcerer, warlock, or wizard
entries: The Mauve Stone is an egg-shaped purple stone. It possesses powerful divination magic, thought he stone comes at a physical cost.
Once per day the Mauve Stone can cast {@spell arcane eye} or {@spell locate creature}.

Once per day the Mauve Stone can cast one of the following: {@spell true seeing}, {@spell contact other plane}, {@spell legend lore}, and {@spell scrying}. Doing so requires a Constitution saving throw {@dc 13} or the caster suffers one level of {@condition exhaustion}.

Once per day can cast {@spell mage hand} and {@spell vampiric touch} simultaneously

Gilda's Ring of Resurrection
entries: This ring has one charge of the spell True Resurrection (see core rulebooks). The ring only functions when it is put on the finger of a dead creature that has been dead no longer than 200 years and returns the creature to life as per the spell. Once used, the ring becomes nonmagical.

item.name: Clockwork Codex
entries: This tome contains instructions, incantations, and rituals neccessary to make clockwork knights and clockwork spiders. To decipher and use the manual, the user must be a spell caster with at least two 5th leve spell slots. Anyone who attempts to use or read the codex suffers {@damage 6d6} psychic damage for each attempt or use, and gains a long-term madness (see core rulebooks). In addition, if they do not have the required spell slots, they must succeed on an Intelligence saving throw DC 20 or gains a random indefinite madness (see core rulebooks).

item.name: Silver Star
entries: This pendant holds a small star inside of it, partially obscured by a cloud of mist. While holding the silver star, you can use an action to determine if an object or location has had a recent interaction with a demon or demonic energy. The star can detect demonic energy up to 15 feet away. However, the closer it's brought towards an item (such as a demonic tome or relic) the brighter the star will glow.

If within 15 feet of an actual demon (or a gate to the Abyss), the star will glow brightly, even if not being actively used. Its brightness will vary depending on how close you are to the demonic presence.

item.name: Emerald Keystone
entries: Speaking into the keystone with a special command world will alow you to influence the thoughts of anyone wearing an {@object emerald pendant|RolledTold12} within 120 feet of you. Anyone wearing the {@object emerald pendant|RolledTold12} is {@condition charmed} to obey the commands of whoever holds the emerald keystone. While the {@condition charmed} creature is wearing an {@object emerald pendant|RolledTold12}, (and so long as you hold the keystone) you have a telepathic link with the creature. You can use this telepathic link to issue commands to the creature while you are conscious (no action required).
The emerald keystone has 8 HP and a 10 AC.

legendaryGroup.name: White Dragon Twins
lairActions: On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), the dragons take a single lair action to cause one of the following effects; the dragons can't use the same effect two rounds in a row:

items: Freezing fog fills a 20-foot-radius sphere centered on a point one of the twins can see within 120 feet. The fog spreads around corners, and its area is heavily obscured. Each creature in the fog when it appears must make a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw, taking 10 ({@damage 3d6}) cold damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. A wind of at least 20 miles per hour disperses the fog. The fog otherwise lasts until the dragon uses this lair action again or until the dragon dies.

Sword-like icicles fall from the ceiling, targeting {@dice 1d4} creatures underneath that the twins can see within 120 feet of it. The twin makes one ranged attack roll ({@hit 4} to hit) against each target. On a hit, the target takes 7 ({@damage 2d6}) piercing damage and must succeed at a Strength or Dexterity saving throw {@dc 10} or be knocked {@condition prone}.

One of the twins targets a single creature within its 120-foot visibility, and if it is touching any icy surface, that creature must succeed on a Strength saving throw {@dc 20} or be under the {@condition grappled} condition from the ice. As an action, a grappled creature can attempt a Strength check {@dc 20} and escape its icy grasp. A creature remains grappled until it escapes, one of the twins uses this lair action again, or the dragons die.

regionalEffects: The region containing a white dragon twin's lair is warped by the dragons' magic, which creates one or more of the following effects:

items: Chilly fog lightly obscures the land within 12 miles of the dragon's lair.
Freezing precipitation falls within 12 miles of the dragon's lair, sometimes forming blizzard conditions when the dragon is at rest.

Icy walls block off areas in the dragon's lair. Each wall is 6 inches thick, and a 10-foot section has AC 5, 15 hit points, vulnerability to fire damage, and immunity to acid, cold, necrotic, poison, and psychic damage.
If the dragon wishes to move through a wall, it can do so without slowing down. The portion of the wall the dragon moves through is destroyed, however.

regionalEffects: If the twin dragons die, the fog and precipitation fade within 1 day. The ice walls melt over the course of {@dice 1d10} days.

legendaryGroup.name: Urswyk
lairActions: On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), Urswyk takes a lair action to cause one of the following effects; Urswyk can't use the same effect two rounds in a row:

lairActions.name: Summon Minion
entries: Up to four skeletons or zombies appear in unoccupied spaces within 30 feet of Urswyk and remain until destroyed. Undead summoned in this way roll initiative and act in the next available turn. Urswyk can have up to four undead summoned by this ability at a time.

lairActions.name: Hard Water
entries: Urswyk targets up to three creatures that she can see within 60 feet of her. Each target must succeed a {@dc 15} Constitution save or be struck by a hardened burst of water and flung up to 30 feet away. A creature that strikes a solid object or falls from midair takes {@damage 1d6} bludgeoning damage for every 10 ft. moved or fallen.

lairActions.name: Ink Burst
entries: Urswyk fills up to four 10-foot cubes of water with ink. The inky areas are heavily obscured for 1 minute, although a steady, strong underwater current disperses the ink on initiative count 10. Urswyk ignores the obscuring effect of the ink.

Goblins are small, black-hearted, selfish humanoids that lair in caves, abandoned mines, despoiled dungeons, and other dismal settings. Individually weak, goblins gather in large-sometimes overwhelming-numbers. They crave power and regularly abuse whatever authority they obtain.

entries.name: Goblinoids
entries: Goblins belong to a family of creatures called goblinoids. Their larger cousins, hobgoblins and bugbears, like to bully goblins into submission. Goblins are lazy and undisciplined, making them poor servants, laborers, and guards.

entries.name: Malicious Glee
entries: Motivated by greed and malice, goblins can't help but celebrate the few times they have the upper hand. They dance, caper with sheer joy when victory is theirs. Once their revels have ended, goblins delight in the torment of other creatures and embrace all manner of wickedness.

entries.name: Leaders and Followers
entries: Goblins are ruled by the strongest or smartest among them. A goblin boss might command a single lair, while a goblin king or queen (who is nothing more than a glorified goblin boss) rules hundreds of goblins, spread out among multiple lairs to ensure the tribe's survival. Goblin bosses are easily ousted, and many goblin tribes are taken over by hobgoblin warlords or bugbear chiefs.

entries.name: Challenging Lairs
entries: Goblins festoon their lairs with alarms designed to signal the arrival of intruders. Those lairs are also riddled with narrow tunnels and bolt-holes that human-sized creatures can't navigate, but which goblins can crawl through with ease, allowing them to flee or to circle around and surprise their enemies. Rat Keepers and Wolf Riders. Goblins have an affinity for rats and wolves, raising them to serve as companions and mounts, respectively. Like rats, goblins shun sunlight and sleep underground during the day. Like wolves, they are pack hunters, made bolder by their numbers. When they hunt from the backs of wolves, goblins use hit-and-run attacks.

entries.name: Worshipers of Maglubiyet
entries: Maglubiyet the Mighty One, the Lord of Depths and Darkness, is the greater god of goblinoids. Envisioned by most goblins as an eleven-foot-tall battle-scarred goblin with black skin and fire erupting from his eyes, he is worshiped not out of adoration but fear. Goblins believe that when they die in battle, their spirits join the ranks of Maglubiyet's army on the plane of Acheron. This is a "privilege" that most goblins dread, fearing the Mighty One's eternal tyranny even more than death.

bonus.name: Nimble Escape
entries: The goblin whelp can take the {@action Disengage} or {@action Hide} action as a bonus action on each of its turns.

action.name: Longsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d8}) slashing damage, or 5 ({@damage 1d10}) slashing damage if used with both hands.
ROLEPLAYING INFORMATION

The Baron is a bone-thin man in his late eighties. His mind is still sharp and he is fairly well read. Even in his current state of poverty, his faded and out-of-fashion garb is always meticulously cleaned and pressed. His age-spotted head is only ringed with snow white hair that matches the well-trimmed mustache that covers most of his mouth. He carries himself with confidence, more for those loyal to him than his own pride.
Ideal: A leader's first duty is to his people.
Bond: Those loyal to me are more precious than gold.
Flaw: A man should trust first and judge after.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: Brother Hovis is a 3rd-level spellcaster. His spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 12}; {@hit 4} with spell attacks). He has the following cleric spells prepared:

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Brother Hovis makes two melee attacks or two ranged attacks.

action.name: Staff
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) bludgeoning damage, or 8 ({@damage 1d10 + 3}) bludgeoning damage if used with both hands.

action.name: Longbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 3} to hit, range 150/600 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d8 + 1}) piercing damage.
ROLEPLAYING INFORMATION

Brother Hovis is tall and bandy as a willow, but hard as an oak. His wild almost lion's mane of hair and equally wild beard, combined with his deep-set eyes and hooked nose, make him an intimidating figure, though his broad smile and booming chuckle is disarming when you are not his enemy. He treats all goodly folk he meets as if they were his to protect and he is never too proud to lend a hand with any of his flocks' work. He is well schooled at arms and armor but abandoned both since finding his calling. Now his faith and a stout stick are all the weapons he feels he needs.
Ideal: There is goodness in every heart.
Bond: The world is a flock and I the shepherd.
Flaw: All folk deserve the benefit of the doubt, until they prove otherwise.

trait.name: Aged Pains
entries: Elder Harra suffers disadvantage on all Dexterity saving throws, and her speed is reduced by -10ft.

trait.name: Aura of Elder's Influence
entries: Whenever friendly creatures are within 10 ft. and can see and hear Elder Harra they gain advantage on a single ability check, attack, or saving throw of their choosing each round. She grants this ability as long as she is not {@condition incapacitated}.

trait.name: Elder's Wisdom
entries: Elder Harra has advantage on all Wisdom ability checks and saving throws.

action.name: Quarterstaff
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 1} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d8 - 1}) bludgeoning damage, or 4 ({@damage 1d10 - 1}) bludgeoning damage if used with both hands.
ROLEPLAYING INFORMATION

Elder Harra is indeed aptly named. She is not only the town elder, but the oldest person in the barony at ninety-nine years. She is quite spry for her age, but not much of a combatant. The tiny, wrinkled woman is highly respected and, after the Baron, her word is law. If she gives an order, even the guards and Guard Captain Starn listen, unless it countermands a direct order from the Baron.
Ideal: An aching back is far better than an aching stomach.
Bond: Simple folk need a voice to stand for them.
Flaw: With age comes wisdom... and arthritis.

trait.name: Iron Willed
entries: Guard Captain Starn has advantage on Wisdom saving throws and saving throws against being {@condition frightened}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Guard Captain Starn makes two melee attacks.

action.name: Longsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) slashing damage, or 7 ({@damage 1d10 + 2}) slashing damage if used with both hands.

action.name: Heavy Crossbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 2} to hit, range 100/400 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d10}) piercing damage.

action.name: Bark Orders {@recharge 5}
entries: Guard Captain Starn gives every ally within 10 ft. that can hear him the ability to immediately take the {@action Dash}, {@action Disengage}, or {@action Dodge} action.
ROLEPLAYING INFORMATION

Guard Captain Starn is a hard but fair man. He wastes no words and feels actions speak more to character than pretty speeches. He is loyal to the Baron and will gladly give his life in defense of him, his holdings, or his people. Starn is barrel chested, but has the skinny legs of one who rides, rather than marches. He is plain featured, looks a bit older than his thirty-odd years, though his pale blue eyes make him look hawkish. He keeps his worn equipment in as good as working order as possible with the state of things in the barony. He may look worn, but is clean and squared away. He expects the same from the guards he leads.
Ideal: Order is the course of the day, gentlemen.
Bond: The Baron's will is my will.
Flaw: Trust is earned, not given.

trait.name: Smith's Grit
entries: Gibbon has advantage on Strength and Constitution saving throws.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Gibbon makes two warhammer attacks.

action.name: Warhammer
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) bludgeoning damage, or 9 ({@damage 1d10 + 4}) bludgeoning damage if used with both hands.
ROLEPLAYING INFORMATION
Gibbon is a hulking youth of twenty with a messy head of red locks and a thin wispy

beard. He is not bright, though a fine hand at basic metal work. He is almost childlike in his mannerisms and thought processes. The big man-boy is easy going, but has a temper as fiery as his forge. He most times has a happy grin on his face. If anyone hurts an animal, a child, or an old person, he will unceremoniously beat them to within an inch of their life.
Ideal: Work hard... be good... be nice to animals.
Bond: I like work'n' metal... and puppies.
Flaw: Now you gone and made me mad!

monster.name: Mischievous Haunt
languages: understands all languages it knew in life

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
entries: The haunt can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. It takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

trait.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: While in sunlight, the haunt has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

trait.name: Linked Haunting
entries: The haunt exists because it is linked to a person, location, or object. As long as what the haunt is linked to exists, so too does the haunt. The haunt may never appear more than 60 feet from this linked anchor. When the haunt is reduced to 0 hit points, it disappears and then returns in 1 round at full hit points. The only way to end this cycle, short of destroying what the haunt is linked to, is by casting a {@spell protection from evil and good} spell on the linked person, location, or object after the haunt has been reduced to 0 hit points and before it returns.

trait.name: Mage Hand Manipulation
entries: The haunt can cast the {@spell mage hand} cantrip at will as a bonus action. The mage hand produced can be {@condition invisible} and may be used with the {@skill Sleight of Hand} skill and to manipulate any tools or objects allowed by the weight limits of the spell.

action.name: Disrupting Touch
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}7 ({@damage 2d6}) psychic damage.

action.name: Stomp and Squish {@recharge 5}
entries: The ogre matron stomps her foot and forces all creatures within 5 ft. to succeed on a {@dc 16} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. Then the ogre matron gets to make an immediate greatclub attack with advantage against any {@condition prone} creatures within reach.

entries: The ogre matron makes a greatclub melee attack.

legendary.name: Mama Says
entries: The ogre matron grants one ogre ally within 60 ft. that can see and hear her an immediate move or attack action.

Creatures that fail are {@condition stunned} until the end of her next turn; those that succeed are {@condition frightened} until the end of their next turn.

trait.name: Reckless

bonus.name: Aggressive

Sheriff Aubrey Griffinstoke is a tall, lean woman in her early thirties. She keeps her russet hair in tight braids to allow nothing to interfere with her vision or drawing her sword should the need arise. She dresses in a loos-fitting work shirt and sturdy trousers, a leather vest, and forester boots. When on duty, she adds a dwarf-made chain shirt and hip quiver to her normal back-mounted sword halter. She is well trained in the fighting arts, though she prefers to try and settle a conflict with words over steel.

entries.name: Ideal
entries: The law doesn't bend, and neither do I.

entries.name: Bond
entries: I serve the good folk of Springkernel proudly.

entries.name: Flaw
entries: Fighting in the last resort.

trait.name: Brave
entries: The deputy has advantage on all saving throws against being {@condition frightened}.

trait.name: Lucky
entries: When Deputy Grubbs rolls a 1 on the {@dice d20} for an attack roll, ability check, or saving throw, he can reroll the die, but must take the new roll.

trait.name: Halfling Nimbleness
entries: Deputy Grubbs can move through the space of any creature that is of a size larger than he is.

trait.name: Stout Resillience
entries: Deputy Grubbs has advantage on saving throws against {@condition poisoned||poison}, and he has resistance against poison damage.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Grubbs makes two melee or two ranged attacks.

action.name: Morningstar
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Shortbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} to hit, range 80/320 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage.

Grubbs is thickly built for a halfling. He always seems in a foul temper when dealing with any race larger than himself. He's surly and gruff, but loyal to a fault. His worn leathers and patched clothing seem to be always in need of a wash. He is never without his ridiculous tall hat that is decorated with several rat skulls and a turkey feather.

entries.name: Ideal
entries: Don't much see a need for talk'in, I'd rather be a-do'n.

entries.name: Bond
entries: Sheriff, she points and I handle it!

entries.name: Flaw
entries: Don't give me no lip, tallstuff. I'll whoop an owlbear, so you ain't no bother!

trait.name: Brave
entries: Opossum has advantage on all saving throws against being {@condition frightened}.

trait.name: Lucky
entries: When Opossum rolls a 1 on a {@dice d20} for an attack roll, ability check, or saving throw, he can reroll the die, but must take the new roll.

trait.name: Halfling Nimbleness
entries: Opossum can move through the space of any creature that is of a size larger than he is.

trait.name: Naturally Stealthy
entries: Opossum can attempt to {@action hide} even when he is only obscured by a creature that is at least one size larger than him.

trait.name: Hunter's Strike (4/Day)
entries: As a bonus action, Opossum can add {@dice 1d10} to his next damage roll with any weapon attack. If the target of the attack is a beast, then he can add {@dice 2d10} instead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Opossum makes two melee or ranged attacks.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Shortbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} to hit, range 80/320 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) piercing damage.

A bandy old halfling who dresses in hunting leathers and a ratty fur vest he claims came from a worg hide, Opossum hires out as a hunter and pest control. Be it foxes after the chickens, or wild pigs or giant gophers messing with the crops, Opossum Gristlepot always gets his prey. He is quite friendly and talkative. He always has a hunting story that gives lessons for every situation... though most seem unbelievable.

entries.name: Ideal
entries: I hunt critters. Don't matter if they walk, swim, fly, or crawl, I'll bring 'em down!

entries.name: Bond
entries: Springkernel is my patch of dirt and I'll not let anything mess with it.

entries.name: Flaw
entries: Ogres ya say? Well that reminds me of the time I tricked two cyclopes into poking each other's eyes out...

trait.name: Antimagic Susceptibility
entries: The animated ice sculpture is {@condition incapacitated} while in the area of an antimagic field. If targeted by dispel magic, the ice sculpture must succeed on a Constitution saving throw against the caster's spell DC or fall {@condition unconscious} for 1 minute.

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While the animated ice sculpture remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a normal sculpture.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The animated ice sculpture makes two melee slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) bludgeoning damage.

monster.name: Chocolate Golem
languages: understands the language of its creator

trait.name: Berserk
entries: When the golem starts it turn with 15 hit points or fewer, roll a {@dice d6}. On a 6, the golem goes berserk. On each of its turns while berserk, the golem attacks the nearest creature it can see. If no creature is near enough to move to and attack, the golem attacks an object, with preference for an object smaller than itself. Once the golem goes berserk, it continues to do so until it is destroyed or regains all its hit points.

The golem's creator, if within 60 feet of the berserk golem, can try to calm it by speaking firmly and persuasively. The golem must be able to hear its creator, who must take an action to make a {@dc 15} Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check. If the check succeeds, the golem ceases being berserk. If it takes damage while still at 15 hit points or fewer, the golem might go berserk again.

trait.name: Aversion to Fire
entries: If the golem takes fire damage, it has disadvantage on the attack rolls and ability checks until the end of its next turn.

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The golem is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The golem has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The golem's weapon attacks are magical.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The golem makes two melee slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

headerEntries: The wizard is a 4th-level spellcaster who uses Intelligence as their spellcasting ability (spell save {@dc 13}; {@hit +5} to hit with spell attacks). The wizard has the following wizard spells prepared:

action.name: Quarterstaff
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 1} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d8 - 1}) bludgeoning damage.

entries: Golda has advantage on saving throws against {@condition poisoned||poison} and has resistance against poison damage.

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Sight
entries: Golda has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing or sight.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Golda makes two melee or two ranged attacks.

entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) slashing damage, or 7 ({@damage 1d10 + 2}) slashing damage if used with both hands.

action.name: Longbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 4} to hit, range 150/600 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) damage.

Golda works as a scout and mountain guide as her father had, though she has been taking on fewer jobs since her grandfather retired and has needed tending to. With the disappearance of the first supply train to the mine, she was asked to lead the second to assure the miners did not starve. True to her clan, she accepted, only to end up captured by orcs. The steely-eyed dwarf maid could have evaded capture, save for the thread of the deaths of the other dwarves with her. So she surrendered, to spare their lives.

entries.name: Ideal
entries: Honor is worth more than any treasure.

entries.name: Bond
entries: A dwarf must do her duty, no matter the cost.

entries.name: Flaw
entries: I'll never let another be harmed in my place.

trait.name: Dwarvan Resilience
entries: Orewick has advantage on saving throws against {@condition poisoned||poison} and has resistance against poison damage.

trait.name: Failing Memory
entries: Orewick suffers disadvantage on Intelligence ability checks and saving throws.

trait.name: Tough as Old Leather
entries: Damage Orewick suffers from nonmagical bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing attacks is reduced by 4.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Orewick makes two melee attacks.

action.name: Battleaxe
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) slashing damage, or 8 ({@damage 1d10 + 3}) slashing damage if used with both hands.

Orewick is a grizzled old warrior. He takes great pride in his fighting prowess, but age, old wounds, and a quickly fading memory has forced in to retire from adventuring. Every year his Intelligence drops by 1d3 points. The old dwarf cares about and never forgets only one thing and that is his granddaughter Golda. With the young dwarf woman missing, he will not be deterred from going to rescue her if possible, or avenge her if not.

entries.name: Ideal
entries: Best way for a dwarf to go out is with an axe in hand and a battle cry on his lips!

entries.name: Bond
entries: If them gritters touch a hair on Golda's head, I'll cleave 'em in twain!

entries.name: Flaw
entries: Sure, I'm ready for a fight... Now where did I put my axe at anyways? Oh, here it is in my hand.

trait.name: Dwarven Resilience
entries: The hammer guard has advantage on saving throws against {@condition poisoned||poison} and has resistance against poison damage.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The hammer guard makes two melee attacks.

action.name: Warhammer
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) bludgeoning damage, or 7 ({@damage 1d10 + 2}) bludgeoning damage if used with both hands. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 12} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Heavy Crossbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 2} to hit, range 100/400 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d10}) damage.

The Clan Hammer Guards are a gritty, grim bunch, though they are boisterous, enjoy gallows humor, and love to sing tavern songs and funeral dirges. They will never choose to flee or leave an ally behind. Every last one will gladly sell their life to aid their clan, allies, and the innocent.

monster.name: Gelid-Frost Twin Young White Dragons

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcaster
headerEntries: Both Gelid and Frost can innately cast three sorcerer spells of 2nd level or lower 1 per day each, requiring no material components. They both use Charisma as their casting ability (spell to hit {@hit +6}, spell save {@dc 14}).

trait.name: Ice Walk
entries: Gelid and Frost can move across and climb icy surfaces without needing to make ability checks. Additionally, difficult terrain composed of ice or snow doesn't cost them extra movement.

trait.name: Innate Metamagic–Twinning {@recharge}
entries: Both Gelid and Frost can each use the Twinned Spell sorcerer Metamagic ability without the spending of sorcery points.

trait.name: Shared Life-force
entries: Gelid and Frost each take half of any damage dealt to them and their twin takes the other half, no matter the distance they are apart. In addition, if one twin dies, so does the other, no matter their current hit point total.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Gelid and Frost make three attacks each, one with their bite and two with their claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d10 + 4}) piercing damage, plus 4 ({@damage 1d8}) cold damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Cold Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: Gelid and Frost exhale an icy blast in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in the area must make a Constitution saving throw, taking 45 ({@damage 10d8}) cold damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one.

legendaryHeader: Gelid and Frost can take 3 legendary actions between them, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action can be used at a time and only by one of the twins, only at the end of another creature's turn. The twins regain their spent shared legendary actions at the start of the twin with the lowest initiative's total turn.

legendary.name: Detect
entries: One of the twins makes a Wisdom (Perception) check.

legendary.name: Tail Attack
entries: One of the twins makes a tail attack.

legendary.name: Cast an Innate Spell (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: One of the twins casts one of the innate spells they know.

legendary.name: Recover an Innate Spell Use (Costs 3 Actions)
entries: One of the twins regains the use of one innate spell.

Ein dunkler Kult, der dem Spiegelgott Zannaz (eine Version von Der {@class warlock||Great Old One warlock patron|great old one}) gewidmet ist, stahl ein weißes Drachenei von einem jungen weißen Drachen. Durch dunkle Rituale versuchten sie, einen zweiköpfigen Drachen zu gebären, der sich ihrem Willen beugen und ihnen dienen sollte. Der Kult wusste nicht, dass das Drachenei einen doppelten Dotter hatte. Normalerweise bringt ein doppelter Dotter nur einen einzigen lebenden Drachen hervor, aber aufgrund der verdorbenen Magie wurden zwei Drachen aus dem Ei geboren. Die weißen Zwillingsdrachen waren geistig und spirituell miteinander verbunden und weitaus mächtiger als andere weiße Drachen. Der Kult nahm dies als Zeichen des Segens ihres dunklen Schutzherrn. Törichterweise überhäuften sie die vermeintlich gottgesegneten Drachen mit mächtigen Ritualen, um ihre ohnehin schon mächtigen Fähigkeiten zu verstärken, und das wurde ihnen zum Verhängnis. Die geistigen Fähigkeiten der Zwillingsdrachen und ihre drakonische Gier wurden ebenso gesteigert wie ihre Zauberkraft. Bald beachteten sie die Befehle des Kultes nicht mehr. Die Drachen schlachteten fröhlich ihre Wächter ab, stahlen alle Magie und alle Reichtümer, die der Kult erworben hatte, und machten sich auf die Suche nach einem eigenen Herrschaftsgebiet. Die neu eröffnete, reiche Goldmine der Zwerge von Craghearth war reif für die Übernahme. Die Drachen planen, die Bergleute auszuhungern und die Bergstadt Stück für Stück ihrer Menschen und Ressourcen zu berauben, bis beides ohne großes Risiko für sie selbst eingenommen werden kann. Die Entdeckung des Orkstammes war nur ein Bonus, sowohl in Bezug auf die Unterhaltung als auch auf die brauchbaren Diener.

headerEntries: The orc frost shaman is a 3rd level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 12}, {@hit +4} to hit with spell attacks).

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The orc frost shaman makes two melee attacks.

action.name: Greatclub
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Frost Eye {@recharge 5}
entries: The orc frost shaman targets one creature it can see within 30 feet of it. The target must make a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw against magic. On a failed save the target creature suffers 10 ({@damage 3d6}) cold damage and is slowed until the end of its next turn, or half as much damage and not slowed on a successful save.
Orcs are savage raiders and pillagers with stooped postures, low foreheads, and piggish faces with prominent lower canines that resemble tusks.

entries.name: Gruumsh One-Eye
entries: Orcs worship Gruumsh, the mightiest of the orc deities and their creator. The orcs believe that in ancient days, the gods gathered to divide the world among their followers. When Gruumsh claimed the mountains, he learned they had been taken by the dwarves. He laid claim to the forests, but those had been settled by the elves. Each place that Gruumsh wanted had already been claimed. The other gods laughed at Gruumsh, but he responded with a furious bellow. Grasping his mighty spear, he laid waste to the mountains, set the forests aflame, and carved great furrows in the fields. Such was the role of the orcs, he proclaimed, to take and destroy all that the other races would deny them. To this day, the orcs wage an endless war on humans, elves, dwarves, and other folk.

Orcs hold a particular hatred for elves. The elven god Corellon Larethian half-blinded Gruumsh with a well-placed arrow to the orc god's eye. Since then, the orcs have taken particular joy in slaughtering elves. Turning his injury into a baleful gift, Gruumsh grants divine might to any champion who willingly plucks out one of its eyes in his honor.

entries.name: Tribes like Plagues
entries: Orcs gather in tribes that exert their dominance and satisfy their bloodlust by plundering villages, devouring or driving off roaming herds, and slaying any humanoids that stand against them. After savaging a settlement, orcs pick it clean of wealth and items usable in their own lands. They set the remains of villages and camps ablaze, then retreat whence they came, their bloodlust satisfied.

entries.name: Ranging Scavengers
entries: Their lust for slaughter demands that orcs dwell always within striking distance of new targets. As such, they seldom settle permanently, instead converting ruins, cavern complexes, and defeated foes' villages into fortified camps and strongholds. Orcs build only for defense, making no innovation or improvement to their lairs beyond mounting the severed body parts of their victims on spiked stockade walls or pikes jutting up from moats and trenches.

When an existing territory is depleted of food, an orc tribe divides into roving bands that scout for choice hunting grounds. When each party returns, it brings back trophies and news of targets ripe for attack, the richest of which is chosen. The tribe then sets out en masse to carve a bloody path to its new territory.
On rare occasions, a tribe's leader chooses to hold onto a particularly defensible lair for decades. The orcs of such a tribe must range far across the countryside to sate their appetites.

entries.name: Leadership and Might
entries: Orc tribes are mostly patriarchal, flaunting such vivid or grotesque titles as Many-Arrows, Screaming Eye, and Elf Ripper. Occasionally, a powerful war chief unites scattered orc tribes into a single rampaging horde, which runs roughshod over other orc tribes and humanoid settlements from a position of overwhelming strength.

Strength and power are the greatest of orcish virtues, and orcs embrace all manner of mighty creatures in their tribes. Rejecting notions of racial purity, they proudly welcome ogres, trolls, half-orcs, and orogs into their ranks. As well, orcs respect and fear the size and power of evil giants, and often serve them as guards and soldiers.

entries.name: Orc Crossbreeds
entries: Luthic, the orc goddess of fertility and wife of Gruumsh, demands that orcs procreate often and indiscriminately so that orc hordes swell generation after generation. The orcs' drive to reproduce runs stronger than any other humanoid race, and they readily crossbreed with other races. When an orc procreates with a non-orc humanoid of similar size and stature (such as a human or a dwarf), the resulting child is either an orc or a half-orc. When an orc produces young with an ogre, the child is a half-ogre of intimidating strength and brutish features called an ogrillon.

bonus.name: Aggressive
entries: As a bonus action, the orc frost shaman can move up to its speed towards a hostile creature that it can see.

trait.name: Opening Volley
entries: The first combat round an orc hunter attacks using a ranged weapon, all weapon damage it does that round deals an extra 5 ({@damage 2d4}) damage per hit.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The orc hunter makes two melee or ranged attacks.

action.name: Battleaxe
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) slashing damage, or 7 ({@damage 1d10 + 2}) slashing damage if used with both hands.

action.name: Longbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 4} to hit, range 150/600 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) damage.

spellcasting.name: Warlock Spellcasting
headerEntries: Nordak is a 7th level spellcaster. His spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 14}, {@hit +6} to hit with spell attacks). Nordak regains his expended spell slots when he finishes a short or long rest. Nordak's arcane focus is an ice crystal.

trait.name: Dwarven Resilience
entries: Nordak has advantage on saving throws against {@condition poisoned||poison}, and resistance against poison damage.

trait.name: Tool Proficiency.
entries: Nordak is proficient with {@item mason's tools|PHB}.

trait.name: Stonecunning
entries: Nordak is considered proficient with Intelligence ({@skill History}) checks related to the origin of stonework, and adds double proficiency ({@hit +9} total) to such checks.

trait.name: Otherworldly Patron
entries: An archfey, the Lord of Sleet and Hail.

trait.name: Eldritch Invocations
entries: Eldritch Sight. Nordak can cast {@spell detect magic} at will, without expending a spell slot.
Repelling Blast. When Nordak hits a creature with {@spell eldritch blast}, he can push the creature up to 10 feet away from him in a straight line.
Silent Image. Nordak can cast {@spell silent image} at will, without expending a spell slot or material components.
Thirsting Blade. Nordak can attack with his pact weapon twice, instead of once, whenever he takes the Attack action on his turn.

action.name: Pact Boon: Pact of the Blade
entries: Nordak can use his action to summon his {@item ice biter handaxe|RolledTold5|frost axe +1} into his empty hand. The weapon disappears if it is more than 5 ft. away from him for one minute. It also disappears if he dismisses it (no action required). The magic weapon appears at his feet if he dies.

action.name: Fey Presence
entries: Nordak's patron bestows the ability to project the beguiling and fearsome presence of the fey. As an action, he can cause each creature in a 10-foot cube centered on him to make a Wisdom saving throw {@dc 14}. Creatures that fail are {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened} (his choice) until the end of his next turn. It can't be used again until he finishes a short or long rest.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Nordak can make two attacks with his frost axe, Ice Biter.

action.name: Ice Biter, +1 handaxe
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) slashing damage, plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) cold damage.

Nordak was a librarian who stumbled upon an ancient text which described the Lord of Sleet and Hail. Seeing a pathway to great power he enacted the rites described in the book, summoning a manifestation of the Lord of Sleet and Hail who he offered his service to in exchange for the arcane abilities the archfey could bestow.

entries.name: Trait
entries: I'm convinced that people are always trying to steal my secrets.

entries.name: Ideals
entries: (Power) Knowledge is the path to power and domination.

entries.name: Bonds
entries: I sold my soul for knowledge. I hope to do great deeds and win it back.

entries.name: Flaws
entries: I am easily distracted by the promise of information.

reaction.name: Misty Escape
entries: Nordak can vanish in a puff of mist in response to harm. When he takes damage, Nordak can use his reaction to turn {@condition invisible} and teleport up to 60 ft. to an unoccupied space he can see. He remains {@condition invisible} until the start of his next turn or until he attacks or casts a spell. Once he uses this feature, Nordak can't use it again until he finishes a short or long rest.

trait.name: Fear of Fire
entries: If the yeti cub suffers fire damage, it has disadvantage on its attack rolls and ability checks until the end of its next turn.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The yeti cub has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell.

trait.name: Snow Camouflage
entries: The yeti cub has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made in snow or icy terrain.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The yeti cub makes two melee claw attacks.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 1} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}2 ({@damage 1d6 - 1}) slashing damage, plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) cold damage.

Yeti tykes are as volatile and mean as their parents, their fearsomeness diminished only by their size. Standing 3 feet tall on average, they like to bully creatures of their height or smaller. But they are easily intimidated by bigger and stronger creatures. A cowed yeti tyke can be controlled, at least for a while, but raising one to be anything other than a savage, flesh-eating predator is incredibly difficult (though not impossible).

trait.name: Fear of Fire
entries: If the vicious yeti takes fire damage, it has disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks until the end of its next turn.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The vicious yeti has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell.

trait.name: Snow Camouflage
entries: The vicious yeti has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made to hide in snowy terrain.

trait.name: Unbridled Blood Rage
entries: If the vicious yeti is reduced to half its total hit points or less, then it gains resistance to all damage, except fire damage and psychic damage.

trait.name: Vicious Claws
entries: The claw attack of the vicious yeti causes 7 extra magic damage on any roll of a natural 20.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The vicious yeti can use its Chilling Gaze and makes two claw attacks.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d6 + 5}) slashing damage plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) cold damage.

action.name: Chilling Gaze
entries: The vicious yeti targets one creature it can see within 30 feet of it. If the target can see the yeti, the target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw against this magic or take 10 ({@damage 3d6}) cold damage and then be {@condition paralyzed} for 1 minute, unless it is immune to cold damage. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If the target's saving throw is successful, or if the effect ends on it, the target is immune to the Chilling Gaze of that yeti for 1 hour.

reaction.name: Summoning Split
entries: If the vicious yeti is successfully hit with a melee attack, it can choose to make an immediate claw attack against any single creature within range.

A yeti's windborne howl sounds out across remote mountains, striking fear into the hearts of the scattered miners and herders that dwell there. These hulking creatures stalk alpine peaks in a ceaseless hunt for food. Their snow-white fur lets them move like ghosts against the frozen landscape. A yeti's icy simian eyes can freeze its prey in place.

entries.name: Keen Hunters
entries: Folk of the high peaks travel in groups and go armed, knowing that yetis can smell living flesh from miles away. When it finds prey, a yeti moves quickly over ice and stone to claim its meal, howling to the thrill of the hunt. Even in a blizzard, the scent of its quarry draws the yeti through the cold and snow.

Yetis hunt in solitude or in small family groups. When creatures flee from a yeti or engage it in battle, other yetis might catch the scent of blood and close in. The territorial yetis fight one another for the spoils of such battles, and yetis slain in the fight are also eaten, amid euphoric howls.

entries.name: Terrifying Howlers
entries: Before an avalanche, a blizzard, or a deadly frost, the yetis' howls sweep down the mountain slopes on the icy wind. Some people of the alpine peaks believe that the voices of loved ones killed in avalanches and blizzards sound out in the wails of the yetis, crying warnings of ill omen. More pragmatic folk attest that the yeti's howl is a reminder that, despite the great accomplishments of civilization, the civilized become the hunted in nature's untamed domain.

entries.name: Brutal Rampagers
entries: When mountain herds are abundant, yetis stay clear of humanoid realms. Driven by hunger, they attack humanoid settlements in waves, breaking down gates and stockade walls that once might have daunted them, then devouring the creatures within.

Devious mountain folk sometimes use the yetis as unwitting weapons. A warlord might lay down slaughtered sheep or goats to draw yetis into an enemy's camp, sowing chaos and thinning the ranks before battle. Mountain clan chiefs, wanting to expand their territory, overhunt local game to diminish the yetis' food supplies, inspiring attacks on humanoid settlements that are swiftly annexed in the aftermath.

entries.name: Abominable Yetis
entries: An abominable yeti is larger than a normal yeti, standing three times as tall as a human. It typically lives and hunts alone, though a pair of abominable yetis might live together long enough to raise young. These towering yetis are highly territorial and savage, attacking and devouring any warm-blooded creatures they encounter, then scattering the bones across the ice and snow.

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Smell
entries: The wolf has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing or smell.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The wolf has advantage on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of the wolf's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

trait.name: Snow Camouflage
entries: The wolf has advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks made to hide in snowy terrain.

trait.name: Army of One {@recharge 5}
entries: As a Bonus Action the Feral Outcast may move up to its speed, not provoking attacks of opportunity and take an Action in addition to its normal Action.

trait.name: Blood Glee
entries: The Feral Outcast does 7 ({@damage 2d6}) extra piercing damage on any melee attack that succeeds against a creature that is not at full hit points or is {@condition prone}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Feral Outcast makes two bite attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 3d6 + 5}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Cold Breath {@recharge 3}
entries: The wolf exhales a blast of freezing wind in a 15-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw, taking 22 ({@damage 5d8}) cold damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

The arctic-dwelling winter wolf is as large as a dire wolf but has snow-white fur and pale blue eyes. Frost giants use these evil creatures as guards and hunting companions, putting the wolves' deadly breath weapon to use against their foes. Winter wolves communicate with one another using growls and barks, but they speak Common and Giant well enough to follow simple conversations.

trait.name: Snow Camouflage

entries: The Alpha makes two bite attacks.

entries: As a Bonus Action, the Alpha can grant any single ally with Pack Tactics to take an immediate {@action Dash}, {@action Disengage}, or {@action Attack} Action, as long as they can see or hear the Alpha.

monster.name: Shackled Soul
languages: understands all languages it knew in life but can't speak

trait.name: Incorporeal Movement
entries: The specter can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. It takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

trait.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: While in sunlight, the specter has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

trait.name: Earthly Remains
entries: The specter can only move 20 ft. away from its remains, held to that length by spectral chains. If the specter is reduced to 0 hit points, unless its remains are destroyed, it regenerates in the same space as them after a short rest.

action.name: Life Drain
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}10 ({@damage 3d6}) necrotic damage. The target must succeed on a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw or its hit point maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the damage taken. This reduction lasts until the creature finishes a long rest. The target dies if this effect reduces its hit point maximum to 0.

A specter is the angry, unfettered spirit of a humanoid that has been prevented from passing to the afterlife. Specters no longer possess connections to who or what they were, yet are condemned to walk the world forever. Some are spawned when dark magic or the touch of a wraith rips a soul from a living body.

entries.name: Beyond Redemption
entries: When a ghost's unfinished business is completed, it can rest at last. No such rest or redemption awaits a specter. It is doomed to the Material Plane, its only end the oblivion that comes with the destruction of its soul. Until then, it bears out its lonely life in forlorn places, carrying on forgotten through the ages of the world.

entries.name: Undying Hatred
entries: Living creatures remind the specter that life is beyond its grasp. The mere sight of the living overwhelms a specter with sorrow and wrath, which can be abated only by destroying said life. A specter kills quickly and mercilessly, for only by depriving others of life can it gain the slightest satisfaction. However, no matter how many lives it extinguishes, a specter always succumbs to its hatred and sorrow.

entries.name: Dwellers in Darkness
entries: Sunlight represents a source of life that no specter can ever hope to douse, and it pains them. When night falls, they leave their final resting places in search of living creatures to slay, knowing that few weapons can harm them in return.
At the first light of dawn, they retreat back into the darkness, where they remain until night falls again.

entries.name: Undead Nature
entries: A specter doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

trait.name: Regeneration
entries: The vampiric minion regains 10 hit points at the start of its turn if it has at least 1 hit point and isn't in sunlight or running water. If the vampiric minion takes radiant damage or damage from holy water, this trait doesn't function at the start of the vampire's next turn

trait.name: Spider Climb
entries: The vampiric minion can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

trait.name: Vampire Weaknesses
entries: The vampiric minion has the following flaws:
Forbiddance. The vampiric minion can't enter a residence without an invitation from one of the occupants.
Harmed by Running Water. The vampiric minion takes 20 acid damage when it ends its turn in running water.
Stake to the Heart. The vampiric minion is destroyed if a piercing weapon made of wood is driven into its heart while it is {@condition incapacitated} in its resting place.
Sunlight Hypersensitivity. The vampiric minion takes 20 radiant damage when it starts its turn in sunlight. While in sunlight, it has disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The vampiric minion makes two attacks, only one of which can be a bite.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 2d4 + 3}) slashing damage. Instead of dealing damage, the vampiric minion can grapple the target (escape {@dc 10}).

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one willing creature or a creature that is {@condition grappled} by the vampiric minion, {@condition incapacitated}, or {@condition restrained}. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) necrotic damage. The target's hit point maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the necrotic damage taken. The reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest. The target dies if this effect reduces its hit point maximum to 0.

spellcasting.name: Wizard Spellcasting
headerEntries: Nija is an 11th level spellcaster. Her spellcasting ability is Intelligence (spell save {@dc 15}, {@hit +7} to hit with spell attacks). Ninja regains her expended spell slots when she finishes a long rest. Ninja's arcane focus is a bone wand. Below are the spells she has prepared. Nija has an additional 12 spells of various levels written in her spellbook of the DM's choice.

trait.name: Infernal Legacy
entries: Nija knows the {@spell thaumaturgy} cantrip. She can also cast {@spell hellish rebuke} as a 2nd level spell (Dexterity saving throw 16) and {@spell darkness} once per long rest. Charisma is her spellcasting ability for those spells.

trait.name: Proficiencies
entries: Dagger, dart, sling, quarterstaff, light crossbow.

trait.name: Arcane Recovery
entries: Once per day Nija can choose to recover expended spell slots after taking a short rest. The spell slots recovered have a combined level of 5th level or lower.

trait.name: Grim Harvest
entries: Nija has the ability to reap life energy from creatures she kills with her spells. Once per turn when she kills with a spell of 1st level or higher, she regains hit points equal to twice the spell's level or three time it if the spell belonged to the School of Necromancy. Doesn't work on constructs or undead.

trait.name: Undead Thralls
entries: When Nija casts animate dead she can target one additional corpse or pile of bones, creating another zombie or skeleton. Nija's undead created using necromancy have the following additional benefits:
-Maximum hit points increase by 11
-The creature adds her proficiency bonus ({@hit +4}) to its weapon damage rolls

trait.name: Inured to Undeath
entries: Nija has resistance to necrotic damage, and her hit point maximum can't be reduced.

entries.name: Background
entries: Hermit

entries.name: Trait
entries: I connect everything that happens to me to a grand, cosmic plan, unleashing the realms of the dead upon the land of the living.

entries.name: Ideals
entries: (Power) Solitude and contemplation are paths towards mystical power.

entries.name: Bonds
entries: My discovery could bring ruin to the world. From that ruin the darkest secrets of necromancy will be mine.

entries.name: Flaws
entries: I harbor dark, bloodthirsty thoughts that my isolation and meditation failed to quell.

trait.name: Draconic Ancestry

trait.name: Magic Resistance

If no creature is near enough to move to and attack, the golem attacks an object, with preference for an object smaller than itself. Once the golem goes berserk, it continues to do so until it is destroyed or regains all its hit points.

headerEntries: Urswyk's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 13}, +5 to hit with spell attacks). She can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: Urswyk can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Horrific Appearance
entries: Any humanoid that starts its turn within 30 feet of Urswyk and can see the hag's true form must make a {@dc 11} Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, with disadvantage if Urswyk is within line of sight, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to Urswyk's Horrific Appearance for the next 24 hours.

Unless the target is surprised or the revelation of Urswyk's true form is sudden, the target can avert its eyes and avoid making the initial saving throw. Until the start of its next turn, a creature that averts its eyes has disadvantage on attack rolls against Urswyk.

trait.name: Undead Minions
entries: Any creature slain by Urswyk's claw attack comes back on its next turn as a zombie under the hag's control. She can have up to three undead thralls at a time.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) slashing damage plus 4 ({@damage 1d8}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Death Glare
entries: The hag targets one {@condition frightened} creature she can see within 30 feet of her. If the target can see the hag, it must succeed on a {@dc 11} Wisdom saving throw against this magic or drop to 0 hit points.

action.name: Illusory Appearance
entries: Urswyk covers herself and anything she is wearing or carrying with a magical illusion that makes her look like an ugly creature of her general size and humanoid shape. The effect ends if Urswyk takes a bonus action to end it or if she dies.

The changes wrought by this effect fail to hold up to physical inspection. For example, Urswyk could appear to have smooth skin, but someone touching her would feel her rough flesh. Otherwise, a creature must take an action to visually inspect the illusion and succeed on a {@dc 20} Intelligence (Investigation) check to discern that Urswyk is disguised.

action.name: Water Form
entries: When submerged in water, Urswyk may magically meld with the water, becoming nearly {@condition invisible}, gaining a +5 bonus to AC and Dexterity saving throws. This effect lasts until Urswyk makes an attack roll. Any equipment she wears or carries is transformed with her.

action.name: Spirit Mastery
entries: Any undead creatures Urswyk has created have advantage on saving throws against effects that turn undead.

action.name: Explosive Charm
entries: Single-use item. When thrown, explodes on contact as per the Fireball spell.

trait.name: Aversion to Fire
