entries: The beast head makes one bite attack against a Large or smaller creature that a grabbing tentacle has {@condition grappled}. If the attack hits, the target takes the bite's damage, the target is swallowed, and the grapple ends. While swallowed, the creature is {@condition blinded} and {@condition restrained}. It has total cover against attacks and other effects outside the beast head, and it takes 14 ({@damage 4d6}) acid damage at the start of each of the beast head's turns.

If the beast head takes 20 damage or more on a single turn from a creature inside it, the beast head must succeed on a {@dc 20} Constitution saving throw at the end of that turn or regurgitate all swallowed creatures, which fall {@condition prone} in a space within 10 feet of the beast head. If the beast head dies, a swallowed creature is no longer {@condition restrained} by it and can escape from the corpse by using 30 feet of movement, exiting {@condition prone}.

Ideal: In life, one must be as relentless as the seas themselves to ensure one's success.
Bond: Not even death will keep me from clearing my family's reputation!
Flaw: There is, indeed, no sacrifice too high to achieve my goals.

Ms. Portia is the no-nonsense sort, with very little to say on matters that don't concern driving schools of fish across long stretches of wild countery. She was born in Deep Fortuna, but refuses to speak about her time there. She considers Mr. Florm a coward and Honorus Klemp a worthless layabout, but won't say much without first imbibing considerable libations.
Ideal: Your business isn't any of mine. And my business is mine alone.
Bond: My cousins in Deep Fortuna don't know that their secret benefactor is actually me.
Flaw: If you can't fight for yourself, don't expect me to.

If a target's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the target is immune to this ghost's Horrifying Visage for the next 24 hours. The aging effect can be reversed with a  {@spell greater restoration} spell, but only within 24 hours of it occurring.

action.name: Corrupting Emotion {@recharge 5}
entries: The ghost releases a torrent of pain and anger. All living creatures within 30 feet must succeed on a {@dc 13} Charisma saving throw. On a failure, a living creature suffers 10 ({@damage 3d6}) psychic damage.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: Sofia is a 4th-level paladin. Her spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 15}, +5 to hit with spell attacks). She has the following spells prepared:

action.name: Plate Gauntlet
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) bludgeoning damage, plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) radiant damage.

Sofia is distressed by her certainty that Queen's Haven is in immediate danger, but she'll never let it show. Time and experience have proven that cooler heads prevail. She is a woman well of wear of her limitations, - both physical and mental, - but nothing will stop her from doing her sworn duty to defend the weak.
Sofia's missing arm limits her in melee; however her faith and experience as a member of the Order of White Ash mean she's not completely helpless.

entries.name: Ideal
entries: It is both an honor and a responsibility to help those less fortunate.

entries.name: Bond
entries: I've been trained to find where darkness takes root. Once I see it, I cannot look away.

entries.name: Flaw
entries: It is hard to trust others when you discover how easily a mortal's heart is swayed.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: Diafol has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Appalling Visions
entries: Once per round, when a creature begins its turn within 60 feet of Diafol, he may force it to make a {@dc 13} Charisma saving throw. On a failed saving throw, the creature takes 10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) psychic damage, and cannot take reactions until the start of its next turn. Roll a {@dice d6} to determine what it does during its turn. On a 1-2 it does nothing. On a 3-4 it makes a Dash action in a random direction. On a 5-6 it attacks a random creature that is not Diafol.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Diafol makes two attacks with his wretched claws.

action.name: Wretched Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) slashing damage.

legendary.name: Bone Shard Volley
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} to hit, range 60/120 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) piercing damage.

legendary.name: Sacrificial Devotee
entries: Diafol calls out to one of his {@condition charmed} subjects, forcing them to run to his side where he may fatally drain them of vitality. Diafol regains 6 ({@dice 1d6 + 3}) hit points.

legendary.name: Disorienting Charm
entries: Flattering whispers fill the mind of a creature Diafol can see within 30 feet. That creature has disadvantage on all attacks against Diafol until the start of their next turn.

legendary.name: Shadow Displacement
entries: Diafol slips into the shadows, melting away from sight and moving to any unoccupied space up to 30 feet away. Use of this ability does not provoke opportunity attacks.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d6 + 1}) slashing damage.
Guards of Queen's Haven are well paid to ensure the safety of its nobility. Stable coin, good meals, clean equipment, and the threat of swift replacement keep their wits sharp and loyalties assured.

actionEntries.name: Skeleton Spawn
entries: {@dice 2d4} skeletons spawn from the skeleton machine each round on the same initiative until it is deactivated or destroyed. This number can be reduced (see Breakdown).

entries.name: Deactivation
entries: Each Dexterity ({@item Thieves' Tools|PHB}) {@dc 20} check counts as 10 Hit Points of damage to the Skeleton Machine. Characters trained in {@skill Arcana} gain advantage on these checks.

entries.name: Breakdown
entries: For every 10 hit points of damage dealt to it, the Skeleton Machine spawns -1 less skeletons until reduced to 0 hit points. Example: when it takes 10 hp of damage it spawns {@dice 2d4 -1}, after 20 hp it spawns {@dice 2d4 -2}, after 30 hp {@dice 2d4 -3}, and at 40 hp it is destroyed.

object.name: Wooden Cage
entries: Door Lock: {@dc 15}

object.name: Ice Wall
entries: The wall is 6 inches thick.

object.name: Pillars
entries: If destroyed, a 20 ft. x 20 ft. section of earth and rock will drop into the chamber causing 21 ({@damage 6d6}) bludgeoning damage, Dexterity Saving Throw {@dc 12} for half. On a failed save, the character is {@condition prone} and {@condition restrained}, Strength check at {@dc 12} to get free.

object.name: Coffin
entries: Each coffin has 4 {@dc 20} locks sealing it shut.

object.name: Staff of Revenant
entries: If the staff is destroyed, each creature in a 15-foot radius must make a Constitution saving throw {@dc 15} or take 16 ({@damage 3d10}) necrotic damage, half on a successful save.

object.name: Emerald Pendant
entries: Donning an emerald pendant immediately submits the wearer to a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw. Failure will submit the wearer to the commands of the {@item emerald keystone|RolledTold12} as per the emerald keystone's effects.
These pendants can be automatically hit so long as they're not being worn. If worn, use the AC of whoever is wearing it unless attacked in a way that won't harm the wearer.

variantrule.name: Alternative Criticals
entries: This section provides alternative critical rules for combat. They can be added as a group or individually to your game.

entries.name: Selective Criticals
entries: Only PCs and significant opponents should be capable of crits, whether you're taking hits or misses. No PC should be laid low because one of the minions got a lucky shot. The woes of the opponents should come at the hands of the party, not the whims of the dice bag. That's just better storytelling.

entries.name: Confirming Criticals
entries: Crits should have to be confirmed, and confirmations stack. Rolling a 20 or a 1 is already pretty badass, because a 20 always hits and a 1 always misses. Getting actual extra damage requires another successful attack roll, and every additional 20 or additional 1 earns you another set of damage to roll for (or an additional penalty). Does extra damage include bonuses like strength or magical bonuses, conventional wisdom says no... a critical hit doesn't mean you got stronger or that your sword got more magical. But you do you. Does a character get advantage or disadvantage on the confirmation roll? Again, I'd say no, but that sounds like a situational consideration to me. Note: where a confirmation roll for a critical hit is another successful attack roll, a critical miss should be confirmed by another failed attack roll!

entries.name: Critical Misses
entries: Critical misses can take an abundance of forms. A critical hit is all about damage, because that's really all that anybody wants it to be about. Critical misses can and occasionally should result in damaging oneself or another party member, but that's not where I think the fun lies. I think the fun lies in negative conditions. It makes more sense to knock oneself {@condition prone} (or {@condition unconscious}!) than simply to do damage to oneself. Or maybe the encounter has a goal, and the critical miss moves the party a step back from that goal. As far as stacking goes, you can worsen the condition, say from {@condition incapacitated} to {@condition unconscious}, or you can add to the duration of the condition, say from one round to {@dice d4} rounds.
Example {@table Critical Misses Table|RolledTold1}

action.name: Dash.
action.entry: The {@i Jabberwock} doubles its base speed to 160 feet per round (140 feet while overloaded).

weapon.name: Swivel Mounted Side-by-Side Repeating Heavy Crossbows
entries: {@item Heavy Crossbow|phb}. {@atk rw} {@h} ({@damage 2d10}) piercing damage. Loads 20 single or 2 stutter-fire shots at once. The Sprocket Glider has 5 reloads (100 shots) in total.

entries.name: Stutter-Fire.
entries: {@atk rw} A 10-foot cube area within range; uses 5 shots of ammunition. Any targets within the target area suffer weapon damage unless they can succeed a {@dc 12} Dexterity Saving Throw to avoid it.

action.name: Duck & Cover.
entries: Any medium-sized creature or smaller in one of the three seats counts as having half cover (+2 to AC and Dexterity saving throws against attacks and effects). A creature in the seats can use an action to take three-quarters cover (increasing the bonus to +5 until their next turn).

action.name: Damage Flaws
entries: Once a Sprocket Glider suffers damage equal to half or more of its total hit points it gains a flaw, and gains another flaw every time it loses a hit point thereafter until destroyed. If not possible to gain another of the generated flaws, the Glider takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) extra damage of the appropriate type.

entries.caption: Sprocket Glider Damage Flaws
rows: {@b Weapon Hit}—The first time this occurs the weapon is jammed and requires a Dexterity check ({@item Tinker's Tools|phb} or {@item Thieves' Tools|phb}) to allow it to be used again. After the second such hit, the swivel mounted crossbow is destroyed. Treat any further results of a weapon hit thereafter as Structural Damage result.
{@b Engine Hit}—The fly speed of the sprocket glider is reduced by 5 ft. This result is cumulative until it is reduced to 0, whereupon it drops from the sky like a stone.

{@b Structural Damage}—The Damage Threshold of the Sprocket Glider is reduced by 1. This result is cumulative until the Damage Threshold is reduced to 0, whereupon no creature in the glider will be granted cover.
{@b Rudder and Flaps}—All Vehicle (Air) checks are made at disadvantage. Any further result of 9-10 on this chart counts as Structural Damage instead.

action.name: Slow Moving.
entries: The Hot Air Balloon takes {@dice 1d6} rounds to air up and cannot take the {@action Dash} action.
